coredata.dc:creator: Delalande, C.
Gale, G.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Experimental observations of the vibrational population relaxation time of n D2 fluid under pressures of up to 500 atm in the 25–85 K range are presented and described in terms of a semi-classical model for energy transfer in liquids. For comparison with the parameters of this model, a classical equivalent potential for quantum systems is derived from the “real” intermolecular potential.

Introduction Recent extensive measurements of vibrational pop- ulation relaxation in liquid hydrogen [1] have stimu- lated the development of a simple semi-classical mod- el for the density dependence of collisional de-excita- tion of large vibrational quantum molecules in simple fluids [2]. The essence of the model is the description of the dynamics of the molecules by an intermolecu- lar potential consisting of a hard core of diameter a plus an attractive well of depth e. The density varia- tion of the vibrational relaxation time is then related to the behaviour of the pair distribution function for the model fluid at contact distance a. This leads to a great simplification in the treatment of many-body effects on relaxation in the compressed fluid, excel- lent agreement with experiment in the case ofH^ was obtained by taking o close to the Lennard-Jones diameter, OIJ , but with e about half e^. This reduced value of the well depth was qualitatively attributed [2] to quantum effects on the density of bound states in the well. A theoretical value for the well depth of quantum systems is obtained in the present paper by introduc- ing, at low density, a classical equivalent potential derived from quantum calculations using the real in- termolecular potential. Comparison with experiment is made both for H^ and for new observations of the population relaxation time of the first excited vibra- 264 tional level ofD^ over a wide range of temperature and pressure (25 85 K, up to 500 atm). Deuterium is of special interest in this context as it has essentially the same intermolecular potential as hydrogen, but is twice as massive: this leads to smaller deviations from classical behaviour than for hydrogen, in quantitative agreement with theory. 2. Conclusions and perspectives A recently developed semiclassical model for the density variation of the vibrational population relaxa- tion time in fluids gives results in quantitative agree- ment with experimental observations in deuterium (and in hydrogen) over a wide range of temperature and pressure by using two, essentially single-valued, parameters: a hard-core diameter of 3.05 A and a well depth of 37 K, which are close to the accepted Lennard-Jones parameters. Practically, the classical well depth, which is the governing factor at low densi- ty, must be corrected for these quantum systems by an analysis of the zero-density quantum pair distribu- tion function of the Lennard-Jones potential. No quantum correction to the hard-core diameter, which is the important parameter at high density, seems to be necessary in this application. This model, which supposes that the absolute re- laxation rates (and hence the isotopic ratios) can be derived from two-body processes and that the density dependence is determined by the variation of colli- sion frequency on a hard core, requires a fuller justifi- cation in the framework of statistical mechanics. Further tests will be provided by the study of more classical liquids. The extension of the formalism to 267 Volume 71, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 April 1980 the case of two-component mixtures and its applica- tion to experiments in the H^/argon system will be presented in a forthcoming paper.
